results.title: Paddington in the hot seat. Paddington's puzzle. Paddington takes a cut.
results.creator_credit: Barry Leith, Ivor Wood, Graham Clutterbuck, FilmFair Communications and Paddington
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The wonderful world of Paddington Bear”.
1. “Paddington in the hot seat”. Paddington has an audience ticket for the Quiz Show “Sage of Britain”. He gets lost in the studio complex and finds himself “on camera” where he is interviewed by Lionel Parr. He disputes the scoring and provides his opinion on proposed changes to British Television. The viewers jam the switchboard and Paddington is announced “Sage of Britain”. - 2. “Paddington’s puzzle”. Paddington makes a jigsaw puzzle as a present for Mr Gruber from a “priceless” old painting discarded by Mr Curry, some plywood and glue. - 3. “Paddington takes a cut”. Paddington reads “Clippings from my Hedgerow” and dreams he is pruning Mr Currys’ shrub into a peacock shape. Disaster strikes when he snips it leg off! However, awakes before discovery by Mr Curry!
results.title_for_label: Paddington in the hot seat. Paddington’s puzzle. Paddington takes a cut.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Barry Leith, Ivor Wood, Graham Clutterbuck, FilmFair Communications and Paddington

results.title: Exhibition formally known as Synthetics (EFKS)
results.brief_description: An exhibition that charts the history of the electronically generated image in Australia from 1969 - 1988 (roughly). Includes case studies by artists whose creative innovations have influenced significantly the evolution of electronic media arts. (see: Documentation for details)
results.description: An exhibition that charts the history of the electronically generated image in Australia from 1969 - 1988 (roughly). results.title: Synthetics. Volume 4
results.brief_description: Volume 4 of a 4 volume CD-ROM collection of material compiled by Stephen Jones for the exhibition formally known as Synthetics. Content is arranged in folders and as a collection of texts, images and hypertexts. The main folder contains material relating to the work of Stephen Jones. (see: Documentation for details)

results.title: Synthetics. Volume 2
results.brief_description: Volume 2 of a 4 volume CD-ROM collection of material compiled by Stephen Jones for the exhibition formally known as Synthetics. Content is arranged in folders and as a collection of texts, images and hypertexts. The folders contain material relating to the work of the following artists: Andrew Quinn, Ariel, David Chesworth, Doug Richardson, Iain MacLeod, Jeff Seidler, Jill Scott, Jon McCormack, Peter Callas, Sally Pryor, Tom Ellard and Wendy Spencer. (see: Documentation for details)

results.title: Cyberdelia
results.credit_line:
Steve Spangaro, director
Mike Collins, associate director
Milena Romanin, production manager
Susan King, interviews and research
Based on an original concept by Adem Jaffers
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
Cyberdelia is a visceral encounter with the aesthetic and ideals of Melbourne underground cyber artists at the confluence of analogue and digital creative practice in 1991.

In blending artist interviews and works, this magazine style documentary explores visions of personal and cultural enhancement through transformative digital technologies. The imminent fusion of spirituality with technology; flesh with machine and psychedelia with cybernetics is confidently proclaimed.

Cyberdelia is a visual and aural feast with the film-makers channelling the post-modern mischief and transcendental yearnings of the ‘cyberdelic’ movement to radical stylistic effect. Stunning cyber artist works are liberally leveraged as both feature material and interstitial fodder. Low-budget analogue video editing and compositing tools are pushed to the limit while artist on-camera interviews are staged in bizarre fashion so as to maintain the feel of a ‘trip documentary’ from start to finish.

Produced for broadcast on community television station RMITV, Cyberdelia stretches the boundaries of arts documentary to portray the brazen idealism and micro-processor powered creativity of these pre World Wide Web visionaries.

Artists: Acid Death Bed, Misha Hollenbach, Troy Innocent (Cyber Dada), Natalie Jeremijenko, Adem Jaffers (Neuro), Jeff Jaffers (Third Eye), Dale Nason (Cyber Dada), Ollie Olsen (Third Eye) Captain ROM, Stelarc, Gus Till (Third Eye), Julian Wong, Christopher Wright and Max Q.

Cyberdelia was generously donated to ACMI by Cyberdelia Productions.
